Comment: An asymmetrical defense. Sapira elects not to fight on Classical lines with 1... P-K4.
The fight for White's Q4 begins at once.
Practically forcing the exchange, as 4 P-K5 overextends White.
White chooses to be the exchanger. With 4 P-Q3 he could have made Black initiate the exchange, but it would have shut in his KB.
5... N-Q2 was the alternative, but this way Black doesn't block in his QB and can unpin with ...N-QB3.
Sapira's one mistake. The correct move was 6... N-KB3!
Thomas pounces at once. The threat is 8 QxP mate!
7... Q-B2 is equally bad [8 BxB ch NxB 9 QxP ch K-Q1 10 NxN and Black can resign.]
If 9... PxN?? 10 QxP mate. So Black instead plays...

This deadly double check forces Black's hand. Sapira resigns at once. His two alternatives are 10... K-N2 11 Q-B7 ch K-R3 12 QPxN mate, or 10... K-K3 11 B-B4 ch with the choice of 11... K-Q3 12 N-B7 ch winning Black's Queen or 11... N-Q4 12 BxN ch KxB 13 N-B7 ch winning Black's Queen.
